MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to Project Gemini! You are sitting in the Gemini capsule on top of a 38 meter high Titan Launch Vehicle. In this lesson, we will prepare the spacecraft to its ready-to-launch configuration.
This spacecraft is far more advanced than Project Mercury and contains more systems, including a computer. I will initially just explain the procedure, then I will highlight what you have to press.

I highly recommend you to complete the Mercury Academy before proceeding with the Gemini academy. A lot of the systems used in Gemini was developed during the Mercury Program, and this builds upon the knowledge from Project Mercury.

The Gemini launch vehicle, names the Titan II, consists of two stages. Stage 1 and Stage 2. Stage 1 will carry the rocket from lift-off and through the lower atmosphere. Stage 1 will then stage, and Stage 2 will carry the rocket into orbit.
The Gemini space craft consists of 3 main parts. The adapter, the retorocket stage and the capsule.

The Adapter contains important equipment needed during a mission. This includes oxygen, orbital attitude maneuvering thrusters, fuel cells (primary power system), etc. It will be jettisoned before the retrograde burn.

The Retrograde section contains 4 retrograde engines that will be fired in sequence during the retrograde burn. This burn is designed to bring the craft onto a re-entry trajectory. After the burn, this stage is jettisoned.

The Capsule is where the crew is sitting and is the re-entry module. This is the only section that will return back to Earth for a safe splashdown in the ocean. The capsule has all systems required after the adapter is jettisoned such as the batteries, secondary oxygen system, the reentry control system for attitude control, etc.
Use [F5] to [F11] to try the different views. Use the arrow keys and page up/down to move the camera manually. Click and hold the scroll wheel while moving the mouse to look around.
You can reassign input from the Settings menu. If you have done so, follow your input configuration when instructions are given. Left click pushes a switch in the left direction, right in the other.
The procedure you will learn now is the PRE-LAUNCH procedure. Later, you can use the PRE-LAUNCH checklist for reference.

Right now, the spacecraft is powered by umbilical power, but once we lift-off, we need to ensure we are running on all the electrical power we got. In short, the spaceship is dependent on two different electrical power systems.

First we have four silver-zinc batteries connected in series inside the capsule itself. The other is a Fuel Cell system located in the Adapter section generating power from Hydrogen (fuel) and Oxygen (oxidizer). The Fuel Cells are the primary power source.

During launch, for redundancy, we want to ensure that all of these systems are powered and operating. This is done by setting all Main Battery switches to ON, and all the FUEL CELL switches to on. I will show you the switches, press ROGER to proceed.
Set Main Battery 1 switch to the ON (UP) position
Set Main Battery 2 switch to the ON position
Set Main Battery 3 switch to the ON position
Set Main Battery 4 switch to the ON position
The spacecraft has two Fuel Cells, each with three stacks producing power (more on this in the Electrical Systems lesson). The fuel cells are our primary source of power.
Set Fuel Cell 1A to ON
Set Fuel Cell 1B to ON
Set Fuel Cell 1C to ON
Set Fuel Cell 2A to ON
Set Fuel Cell 2B to ON
Set Fuel Cell 2C to ON
Power the Fuel Cell Section #1
Power the Fuel Cell Section #2
The Main DC Bus is now powered by both systems.
As in Project Mercury, the pyrotechnics are used to create controlled explosions to separate redundant rocket parts(staging) and to jettison components from it.
The pyrotechnics are dependent on an isolated power system, the Common Controls Bus.

This system is powered by three Silver-Zinc Squib batteries, and should stay ON for the duration of the entire mission. These are turned on by setting the three Squib Battery switches to the ON position. Are you able to find them? Press ROGER and I will show you where they are.
Set Squib Battery 1 switch to the ON position
Set Squib Battery 2 switch to the ON position
Set Squib Battery 3 switch to the ON position
The Common Control Bus is now powered, and is ready to be used when needed.

For safety reasons, this system needs to be armed as well. To do this, we are next going to set the BOOST-INSERT to ARM. This will arm all the squibs needed during the launch and insertion stages of the mission.
Set the BOOST-INSERT switch to the ARM position
For safety reasons, all the four retro rocket engines will also be set to ARM during launch.
This is to be able to use the RETRO ENGINE in case of emergencies, never know when you need them. Set Retro Squib #1 to ARM
Set Retro Squib #2 to ARM
Set Retro Squib #3 to ARM
Set Retro Squib #4 to ARM

Next we will turn on the On-Board Computer (OBC). The OBC is AC powered through something called the inertial measurement unit (IMU), and the Main DC Bus using an internal inverter. The nertial measurement unit are gyros used for attitude information.
All that is needed to turn on the computer is to set the power to ON.
When on, the computer will perform some internal self-tests. The computer display and keyboard is located on the pilot side (right seat) but is currently turned off, let us power it.
Turn on the MDIU by setting its Power switch to ON.
You might see the On-Board Computer (OBC) self-tests running, indicated by the address and message digits rolling on the computer display.

These self-tests lasts for about 20 seconds after powering the computer. The display will be stationary when complete and normally reset to all ZEROS. If not, you can press CLEAR to reset the display.

The next step is to verify that the D-RING has been installed (this is installed by default). The D-RING is a handle located on the seat, just between the feet of the astronaut. This ring has a red/yellow striped pattern.
During a pad abort or an abort right after lift-off, the D-RING is pulled to eject the seat out through the hatch.
You can toggle the D-RING on or off using the TOGGLE D-RING function bubble (toggle them on or off using [C]) just below the commanders panel. Try to toggle this off and on.
Let's set up the environmental control system (ECS).
In short, the cooling of the spacecraft is done by a liquid cooling system going through all our components. Using coolant, heat exchangers, radiators and systems will stay cool.
The spacecraft has two independent cooling systems. Using pumps, the coolant flows through the systems.
Set Primary Coolant Pump A to ON
Verify Primary Coolant Pump B is OFF
Set Secondary Coolant Pump A to ON
Verify Secondary Coolant Pump B is OFF

Each astronaut has a pressurized suit, each operating independently from each other. Oxygen is circulated through these loops, and carbon dioxide and odors are removed. The gases are cooled in a heat exchanger by the coolant loop.
Compressors are used to circulate the oxygen through each suit loop. In one loop, two compressors exist, one primary and one alternate compressor. Both are active during the entire mission.
Set the SUIT FAN to the DOWN 1&2 position to turn on both fans (compressors) during launch.
You can monitor the cabin and suit temperature using this gauge. The coolant pumps and fans will be on until adapter separation, where they will be jettisoned with it.

Next we will power the computer, but before that I want you to locate the Attitude Direction Indicator (ADI) ball on the commanders panel (left seat). This is the "8-ball" in the center of the panel. The pilot side (right) also have this.
This ball is used to show you the current attitude of the space craft, relative to an inertial platform stored in the inertial measurement unit (IMU).
We will soon start the computer. Once you start the computer, I want you to immediately look at the commanders attitude direction indicator ball (ADI).

The computer needs to be turned on in the PRE-LAUNCH mode, and once the self-check is complete (verify the computer displays address/message digits are stationary and all zeros), it can be started by pressing the START button in the computer section of the center pedestal panel.
Quickly look at the ADI and press ROGER once you have the ADI in view, this is the 8 ball.
When the computer is running in PRE-LAUNCH, the computer will spend 45 seconds on aligning the platform. You can see the attitude indicator balls rotate to the programmed launch azimuth.
The attitude indicator ball will roll fast at first, and then fine align (you can barely notice any movement). As mentioned, the total alignment takes about 45 seconds.
It is important to not interrupt this process. The alignment will configure the roll program so it will roll correctly to reach a heading, and a set target inclination.

When the alignment is complete (after 45 seconds or when you see the ADI ball being stationary), configure the computer to prepare the ASCENT program. This is pre-loaded into memory, meaning that it can be loaded instantly (no program loading time required - more on this in the computer lesson).
In general, if the COMP light is green, the computer is working. If the MALF light is amber, a reset is required.
The COMP light should now be gray. An on-board sequencer will automatically turn on the computer at lift-off. When this happens, the indicator will illuminate GREEN.
Do not press this now, but if the COMP light is not illuminated green at liftoff, start it manually by using the START button.
Set the attitude control mode to rate command. We will cover this in a later lesson but this is basically a control mode that allows the astronaut to manually manuever the spacecraft attitude.
The reason for it being set now is in case of an abort where the capsule orientation might need additional help to reach a retrograde attitude.
We will also open the fuel valves for to main attitude control mode called Orbit Attitude and Maneuvering System (OAMS).

The Orbit Attitude and Maneuvering System is a set of thrusters located on the Adapter module of the space craft. These are the thrusters that allows the capsule to orient and translate when in orbit.
Since the Adapter is jettisoned before Reentry, additional thrusters exist on the capsule, designed to be used for attitude control after adapter jettison and during Reentry.
The Reentry Control System has two independent sets of jets used to orient the craft, called RING A and RING B. Both rings can be used independently or together for attitude control.
Next we will open the fuel valves for the Reentry Control System (RCS) RING A.
Then we will open the fuel valves for Reentry Control System (RCS) RING B.
Both the Orbit Attitude and Maneuvering System and Reentry Control System Ring A/B fuel valves should now be open, and ready for use in-case of an abort.
A Manual Data Insertion Unit (MDIU) allows the pilot to communicate directly with the computer.
During the pre-launch procedures, the pilot will use the Manual Data Insertion Unit (MDIU) to insert 72 into the computers address field.

Address 72 is the memory address of the Inertial Velocity value. If this is needed during ascent or an abort, the computer should already be configured to display the Inertial Velocity and all the crew needs to to is to press the READ OUT button.
Start by pressing 7 on the Manual Data Insertion Unit (MDIU) aka. the computers keyboard.
Then press 2 on the Manual Data Insertion Unit (MDIU).
The computer is now ready to display the inertial velocity upon need during ascent.

Many of these pre-launch steps are to ensure that the configuration and panel interaction is kept to a minimum during ascent and in-case of aborts. This is because its hard to work with the panels when the cockpit is shaking, and easy to forget steps during the stress of an abort.
The last step is to make a radio check. Press the [C] RADIO CHECK function bubble to do this.

Normally, when the countdown reaches zero, the rocket will launch and ascend into orbit. Feel free to take a look around the cockpit to get familiar with it, and reference the panels as you study the Gemini Flight Manual.
Thats it for now, see you in the next lesson. [Mission complete.]

Title: Tutorial 1 - Pre-Launch
Description: This lesson covers the final steps for preparing the Gemini spacecraft for launch. These steps include turning on internal power, setting up the computer, the squibs and the environmental control system.
